text: 12 Ways a Standup Comedy Will Make You Healthier

Ever had one of those days where everything seems to go wrong? Enter the world of stand-up comedy. A realm where comedians like Taylor Tomlinson and Daniel Sloss take the stage, share their quirky observations, and make you forget your worries, even if just for a moment.
The Science Behind Laughter üòÑ
Laughter isn't just a response to a funny joke; it's a complex physiological and psychological process. Here's what happens when you chuckle:

Physiological Changes: Laughter increases heart and respiratory rates, as well as oxygen consumption. After the initial burst, you move into a state of relaxation. In fact, 10-15 minutes of laughter per day might burn 10-40 extra calories.
Heart Function: Laughter affects heart function by increasing stroke volume, cardiac output, and dilating blood vessels.
Stress Reduction: Laughter lowers levels of the stress hormone, cortisol.
Brain Chemistry: It activates the mesolimbic dopaminergic reward system in the brain.
Immunity Boost: Laughter increases serum immunoglobulins A and E, potentially increasing natural killer cell activity.
Feel-Good Chemicals: It raises levels of beta-endorphins and increases human growth hormone.
Laughter and Health Conditions üè•
Laughter isn't just good for the soul; it's beneficial for the body too:
Heart Health: There's an inverse association between coronary heart disease and propensity to laugh.
Diabetes: Watching a comedy show decreased the overall rise in glucose levels after eating.
Mood Boost in Cancer Patients: Laughter therapy improved self-esteem and mood in cancer patients.
Lung Health: Laughter reduced hyperinflation of the lungs in people with severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Cognitive Function: Humor therapy led to improvements in cognitive function in older adults.
https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541863145320-15f769891592?auto=format&fit=crop&q=80&w=1374&ixlib=rb-4.0.3&ixid=M3wxMjA3fDB8MHxwaG90by1wYWdlfHx8fGVufDB8fHx8fA%3D%3D

Embracing Laughter in Our Lives
Remember, it's not just about recommending laughter but intentionally bringing it into your daily life. Share a joke, watch a comedy show, or even try laughter yoga.
[The Healing Benefits of Laughter](https://www.va.gov/WHOLEHEALTHLIBRARY/tools/healing-benefits-humor-laughter.asp)
